posts.cooked:
Hi all,

I'm interested in gathering your thoughts before my team regroups to make a decision. Recently, we competed at the North Star Regional with our Kitbot, equipped with a tank drive and shallow climb capability. The robot performed well for us, serving as a solid teammate and encountering only minor issues that were easily resolved. We made adjustments to our autonomous navigation and raised the height of our shallow climb. Despite not securing an alliance, we had a fantastic experience, learning a lot. Last year, our robot underperformed significantly, making this year’s improvements a notable step forward for us.

Since returning, we’ve explored the possibility of switching our drive system. Our team has used a tank drive since its inception, except for one year when we briefly tried an Omni drive, which didn’t work out, so we returned to tank. I pitched the idea of trying a different drive system to our coach, who expressed interest in mecánum, believing it could offer improved maneuverability on the field. While I’m passionate about ultimately migrating to swerve, which I believe could significantly enhance our team’s capabilities, the coach suggests starting with mecánum as a transitional step to build foundational skills before diving into swerve.

However, I’m concerned about our limited summer timeframe. Balancing mecánum implementation with swerve migration could strain our schedule, potentially hindering our ability to focus on functionality during the season. Additionally, I wonder whether mecánum would truly address our mobility issues, particularly in aligning with stations and maintaining consistent positioning after scoring.

Looking ahead, I’d love to see us transition to swerve in the long term, as it offers advanced features that could greatly benefit our competition performance compared to our current tank drive. But first, I’m curious whether mecánum would provide immediate, tangible improvements, especially given our coach’s enthusiasm for it. If mecánum proves effective, perhaps we can gradually introduce swerve later.

I’d welcome any insights or advice you have on this topic. Based on the photo provided, does switching to mecánum represent an upgrade over our current setup? How challenging would integrating mecánum be with our existing drivetrain, and would it compromise our current functionality?

Your thoughts would be invaluable as we plan our next steps toward improving our robot’s mobility and performance.

---

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
My response to your coach would be that Mecanum is not a step on the way to swerving. Swerve is a completely different drivetrain, requiring a different setup entirely. Mecanum may be easier to install on a kit chassis, though it often necessitates additional gearboxes, whereas Swerve is becoming increasingly manageable with the right components. Still, Mecanum demands a fundamentally different mechanical and programming configuration. Practically speaking, Mecanum systems that aren't designed similarly to Swerve should function like a tank drive, while Mecanum systems mimicking Swerve mechanics will likely fall short compared to actual Swerve systems.

However, there's one thing I wouldn't say to him: "Some teams see Mecanum and immediately disqualify others based on that alone," even though it's true, it's not something I believe needs emphasis.

Interestingly, Rookie teams are already achieving success with Swerve drives, as highlighted in the linked thread. The data suggests that Swerve remains the predominant drive system in competition today.

Regarding whether switching to Mecanum represents an improvement over current setups, I would advise against it. Mecanum is more likely a step backward. If I were in your position, I'd focus on optimizing Swerve performance and driving it to its fullest potential before considering any upgrades during the offseason.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
We spent from our Rookie year (2015) to last season as a Tank. Towards the end, we moved from CIMs to NEOs for our drive motors. That was quite a difference. We changed the white wheels to black for better traction.

At the end of the school year last year, we made the switch to swerve. We pieced the swerve system over the last few years, buying parts as we could afford them. This year, we ran swerve for the first time.

There is a knowledge gap we needed to overcome, and we are still learning.

Bottom line: If you want a Corvette, never settle for a Chevette. There are a lot of swerve options available, and coding isn't that bad. There is also a lot of help out there if you run into problems.

I would make the leap into swerve if I were you; you will never look back.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked: "I saw this topic and thought that someone had made a post to an open topic from 2019. Mecanum can be a fun academic exercise as part of exploring the history of drivetrains when you have nothing else to use. It’s not suitable for competition today. Get busy on an off-season swerve drive. While the basics are straightforward, there is a lot to learn in terms of tuning, driver practice, accurate auto path following, and maintenance that you don't want to deal with in-season. We've been doing swerve for four years and still find new things. Mecanum won't help you get there in any way."

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: "My opinion is that mecanum is a dead end. If it is at all affordable to you, I would look to the example of teams such as 9092 and 9543 (I'm sure there are others; I'm just familiar with these two). They built kitbots in their rookie year and then in year 2 essentially built a kitbot (or kitbot-like) but with a swerve drivebase and saw their performance increase substantially."

Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can achieve maximum efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will perform well. Additionally, consider enhancing software to assist your driver. Each Venom model comes equipped with internal encoders, so experiment with utilizing them to improve auto functions or create driver aids.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Rookie year (2015)... Towards the end...we moved from CIMs to NEOs for motors. Off topic but... What? Ah nvm I see what you meant. Regardless: Your point stands: a simple motor upgrade has an impact from basic CIMs. But there is some sort of detail wrong here, rev was founded in ~2014/2015 and the NEO was but a twinkle in Greg and co.'s eye in '15. 2015-2017 was the era of some wacky (and cool) drivetrain ideas.
Please do not do mechanum. What was previously mentioned about "do not pick" lists is accurate.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: We switched to NEOs in 22 for our drivetrain. When you're a small, underfunded team, you do what you can.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
To the OP:

I watched your North Star matches. I’ve been involved in the design of numerous FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) robots, have helped to start several FRC teams since 1996, and have 40+ years of motor engineering background. Your team played well with the basic L1 design this year. More pushing power would have given a small advantage; however, mecanum drive would have been a very significant disadvantage.

FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) is a great program, and mecanum drive does perform well there. In Michigan, FTC is limited to middle school teams, and many of our best FRC students progress to important roles after starting in FTC. None of those students would recommend mecanum for an FRC robot.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
This is as comprehensive an answer as anyone could give, and I agree with all parts of it.  

OP, don’t bother with Mecanum. It’s not worth the headache nowadays. I’m not convinced it was ever worth the headache.  

If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. This makes programming a competent Mecanum drive far more difficult than it looks on the surface.  

I spent 2 years mentoring 3007, a team from your neck of the woods who insisted on Mecanum year after year. We had mentors who were well-versed in wrangling Mecanum’s quirks in code. We had good habits around checking rollers for debris between matches. WE STILL NEVER DROVE STRAIGHT.  

Back then, there was (sort of) a case for Mecanum. Yes, it was fiddly, you never drove straight, and you always moved slower than everyone else, but you couldn’t get t-boned and tight field geometry wasn’t a hindrance. Nowadays, Swerve delivers on all of Mecanum’s advantages, does a better job at those advantages than Mecanum can, and has none of the fiddly in-competition annoyances.  

The only game I can think of where Mecanum could have had a net advantage over tank was 2015—a game unlike any other in the RIO era—and Mecanum STILL didn’t work great because the weight of the totes threw your CoG totally out of whack while you placed a stack. You either couldn’t drive straight while going to the feeder, or you couldn’t drive straight while placing a stack. Pick your poison.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Concurring opinion. It is possible to have an effective and inspiring mecánico robot. Team 6167 used an Everybot mecánico in captain roles at their last two FSC events, though they faced some challenges: they managed to stay out of the way and contribute with processor algae, which added significant value. Additionally, having the Everybot climb provided a unique advantage in FSC compared to other events, as several top teams chose not to climb. This year's game was particularly favorable for mecánicos due to shorter sprints, which masked the reduced power compared to games like Crescendo or Charged Up. This wasn't their first time competing with a mecánico.

Despite these successes, I still feel the "swerve tax" has had a negative impact on many teams' strategies. However, mecánicos continue to evolve, especially in 2025. Looking ahead, there are two promising options: either the AM14U6 chassis from the kit with HiGrip wheels, paired with a Toughbox Mini ratio and drivetrain motor—possibly upgraded with an 8WD kit for durability—or implementing a COTS swerve. The latter, when executed correctly, offers a higher competitive ceiling. If a team prefers not to pursue swerve due to resource constraints, the former option remains a viable and justified choice.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Spend all the time you'd invest in making mecanum work into fundraising the money you need for a swerve drive.  

With YAGSL and other code solutions for swerve sitting there ready to go, the barrier to entry for a good swerve chassis is really just the money.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. This makes programming a competent Mecanum drive far more difficult than it looks on the surface.

Thank you for clarifying why mechanum is a headache instead of just saying don’t. In perfect scenarios, mechanum is pretty streamlined to get online and functional, and you hop straight to having a holonomic drive train. For this year’s Kitbot, CG is relatively solid, and it might actually make a viable mechanum bot. However, you still need to double up on gearboxes (since each wheel needs its own drive), on top of the wheels, so this reduces cost savings a bit.

However, CG is not the worst aspect. The moment your frame gets even slightly tweaked, you balance on two opposing wheels, losing control in both axes of motion. This is what happened to us in 2015, which was the first and last year we tried running mechanum. We just ran straight tank until 2024, well after being completely dominated by swerves, but never even seriously considered mechanum again.

For an interesting cost-saving tip, you only need two swerve modules to make a swerve bot. Put them on a diagonal, and use omnidirectional wheels for the other corners. This is what our practice bot runs, and it works perfectly. The main snag is that most “builder” tools do actually expect 4 modules, so you kind of just ignore two of them and adjust parameters a bit. We use Yagsl, and we actually don’t even need to modify code between our two-swerve practice bot and our normal bot. I wouldn’t pitch this for a competition bot, but for a practice testbed? Absolutely.

the cleaned-up version: If your center of gravity isn't perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you'll never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. Actually, even more generally, Mecanum drives rarely drive straight even if the CG is centered and your frame is built to good tolerances unless you solve a rather complicated controls problem. The easiest way to demonstrate it is to drive a Mecanum drive bot forward, then suddenly sideways. Two of the wheels need to switch directions, but because the wheels and robot have inertia and non-zero latency, the robot skews, and you aren't driving straight anymore. This isn't unsolvable, but it is beyond the capabilities of almost every FRC team to solve, hence why most Mecanum FRC and FTC bots don't drive straight to some degree or another unless driven slowly. It is possible to solve this problem—I've personally done so—it's really hard (you need to use a Cartesian-space inverse dynamics controller, while extrapolating out latency and avoiding voltage, current, and traction saturations). Swerve is just less susceptible to these issues due to having more traction and throwing 400W brushless motors at the problem. ``` Okay, I need to help the user clean up this technical text. I would not recommend mechanum if you are looking to be a more competitive robot. While it’s used for FTC robots, mechanum allows your robot to be more easily pushed around. There was only one robot at one of our competitions this year that had mechanum, and it was constantly being pushed around by defending robots or the bots it was trying to defend, leading it to be placed on our no-pick list.

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked:
I’m not trying to dissuade you from a learning opportunity. However, our team has used Mecanum once. We only used it in 2021, during the COVID year. There’s no real defense, but it was quite flashy for a team that couldn’t run Swerve.

I’d highly recommend trying out Swerve if you can gather the funds. There are a lot of great tools available. For coding, there’s YAGSL, Yet Another Generic Swerve Library. There are excellent widening guides and SDS, Swerve Drive Specialties, which is mechanically very straightforward. Just don’t put magnets upside down.

However, it’s expensive, and as far as I know, our team is fortunate to have generous sponsors. I’d suggest looking for a grant from a sponsor specifically for a Swerve base. They might be more inclined to support your project if they see the innovation and STEM behind what they’re supporting.

link_counts.title: FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Driver practice is more impactful than drivetrain performance. If a driver can achieve peak efficiency with their current drivetrain, they will excel. Drive practice is crucial and swerve offers significant advantages. Swerve is easy to build—cut 4 2x1 tubes to suitable lengths, attach modules, and create a belly pan from 5mm plywood. Once the robot size is decided, practice driving can begin quickly. Swerve provides "field-oriented" controls, making driving much easier. This approach was used in their 2012 "Barbie Bot" swerve.
